page.lettertext:
fol.224r
May it please yo
r
good L. Heere are certaine
Ambassado
rs
come
newly to the Hage from the
Elector Palatin
, to witte the
Baron of Winningbergh
and his sonne, and one
Mons
r
Durant
a Frenche man and a secretary to the Electo
r
. They have
already had accesse to the
General states
: and their message
contened these principal pointes. A gratulation unto them
for the good successe that they have had, in the administrac
o
n
of their gouvernment. A remonstrance of the losses, that the
Electo
r
hath sustened by the death of
D. Cassimir
. The
maner of his comming to take possession of his contreis:
wherin he pleadeth for himself, that by an ancient privilege
of all his predecesso
rs
, he was out of his wardshippe at 8
yeres of age: although that Bulla aurea doe appoint him
a gardian till the age of 25. A declaration of the trou-
bles unto w
ch
he is brought by the violent intrusion of
e
D. of Simeren
his grand Uncle. His complaint unto
the
Empero
r
,
for redresse of those wronges. The Empe-
rors refusall to shew him any favo
r
. The intercession of
certaine Princes, to make an appointment between him
and his Uncle. The doubt that he conceaveth
at their
endevors will be frustrat. A specification of divers in-
conveniences,
at are likely to ensue if he should be overbo
r
e
by the might of his enemies: wherin not onely he himself
and the cause of religion w
t
the Princes of Germany
but the state of these contreis, and the
F
r
Kinges
affaires
will be greatly prejudiced. Lastly his intention to stand in
defence of the right of his cause: wherto he made request, if
his enemies would oppresse him, to be assisted from hens
w
t
men and mony. This is the summe as I am informed
of all that they proposed. And because there can be noe
answear delivered heere unto them till every several Province
hath considered of the mater, they doe therefore determine to
fol.224v
To
[.]
June 20 1592
goe presently for England, and returning backe againe, to ta
[ke]
answear of the states. For as farre as I perceave by their
[.]
speeches unto me, they are chiefly sent unto her Ma
tie
to nego
[tiate]
in effect the same as they doe heere: and to make restitution
[.]
the garter of D. Cassimir, and of the booke of statutes app
[er]
taining to the order. It is resolved by the states upon the
[.]
instaunt intreatie of the Captaines and Commaunders of the
[.]
forces in
France,
at they shall be revoked. For it seemes tha
[t]
they are not 500 in number: w
ch
doe greatly complaine of
all maner of wantes: and
Count Philip
of their fewenes
for w
ch
he thinkes it no hono
r
, to be there any longer. How
be it it is permitted to the Kinge, if his neede so require,
[to]
retene a convenient number, to be placed in garrison, in so
[me]
good towne of
Normandie.
&c. June 25.
